docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In 2004, when my wife received a diagnosis of lymphoma, we were lucky: we had dedicated doctors and nurses, as well as insurance from her employer, for what was a long and expensive treatment. Now I read that Genentech prices its drugs based on ''the value of innovation, and the value of new therapies.'' What does this mean? Isn't it just a euphemism for the fact that Genentech charges what it perceives the ''market'' will bear for its ''commodity'' -- your health?

headline.main: When a Longer Life Costs Too Much

docs.abstract: Russell McDonald letter charges that Genentech intends to sell its cancer drug Avastin at whatever price it believes the market will bear (Feb 15 article); says America's blind obsession with free markets allows Americans to be extorted by pharmaceutical and insurance industries
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     In 2004, when my wife received a diagnosis of lymphoma, we were lucky: we had dedicated doctors and nurses, as well as insurance from her employer, for what was a long and expensive treatment.      Now I read that Genentech prices...

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association has signed a pact with Congress promising to develop more than 100 standard measures of performance, which doctors will report to the federal government in an effort to improve the quality of care. The deal comes as the Bush administration pushes ''pay for performance'' arrangements with various health care providers in an effort to publicize their performance and link Medicare payment to quality. And it mirrors efforts in the private sector, where consumer groups, insurance companies and large employers who pay for health care are demanding more information on the quality of care.

headline.main: A.M.A. to Develop Measure Of Quality of Medical Care

docs.abstract: American Medical Assn promises Congress that it will develop more than 100 standard measures of performance, which doctors will report to federal government in effort to improve quality of care; performance measures are supposed to focus on diagnostic tests and treatments that are known to produce better outcomes for patients; idea has strong support in Congress and from AARP, but many doctors fear information could be used by government to justify cutting their Medicare fees (M)
docs.snippet: The American Medical Association has signed a pact with Congress promising to develop more than 100 standard measures of performance.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Genentech has decided to price the cancer drug Avastin at $100,000 per year for doses tested for lung and breast cancer. It argues that the drug saves more lives than previous treatments, so people should be willing to pay whatever it charges. Next, I suppose, we will learn that because a baby aspirin a day can help protect against strokes or heart attacks, St. Joseph and Bayer have decided to charge $100 per pill for coated aspirin purchased for people over 60.

headline.main: When a Longer Life Costs Too Much

docs.abstract: Teresita C Schaffer letter questions Genetech's pricing of cancer drug Avastin at $100,000 a year (Feb 15 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Genentech has decided to price the cancer drug Avastin at $100,000 per year for doses tested for lung and breast cancer. It argues that the drug saves more lives than previous treatments, so people should be willing to pay whatever...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 U.S. Troop Withdrawal Hinges on Elite Iraqi Teams The Bush administration's plans for troop withdrawals from Iraq are anchored on increasingly capable Iraqi security units. American Special Operations Forces commanders say they have begun training elite Iraqi teams to take over the most sensitive missions. A1 Freeze on Palestinian Revenue Israel's cabinet decided to freeze the transfer of about $50 million a month in tax and customs receipts due to the Palestinian Authority, arguing that a Hamas-dominated legislature means that the Palestinians are now led by the militant group. A1 Grim Acceptance in Philippines A turning point has been reached in the Philippines as officials and villagers begin to wrestle with early warning signs that were ignored, and with accepting the scope of the mudslide disaster that may have killed more than 1,800 people. A1 Tension Over Holocaust Files Tempers are flaring over a United States demand to open to scholars and researchers a huge repository of information about the Holocaust contained in the files of the International Tracing Service at Bad Arolsen, Germany. A3 Cracks in Canada's Health Care In Canada's public health care system, several large provinces are opening the way for private health care. The Quebec government proposed to lift a ban on private insurance for some elective surgeries. A4 Attacks in Iraq Kill 17 At least 17 people were killed in insurgent attacks, and talks on a unity government among Iraq's political factions remained deadlocked less than a week before the new Parliament's first meeting. A5 Bird Flu Migrates Quickly The first reports of bird flu that cropped up in widely separated countries -- India, Egypt and France -- highlighted the disease's accelerating spread to new territories. A6 Law Abuses Charged in Mexico In Mexico, attempts to jail Lydia Cacho, who had written a book about child pornography and pedophile rings in Cancún, have raised questions about the rich and powerful using their influence to silence critics. A7 Kenyan Fights Corruption With Kenyan cabinet ministers resigning and the police seizing the passports of officials linked to corruption, John Githongo, the onetime government insider behind it all, says an important corner may have been turned in the fight against corruption. A7 Gas Explosion in Mexican Mine In Mexico scores of coal miners were trapped deep underground when a gas explosion caused an avalanche of rock that sealed off a mine shaft in the border state of Coahuila, state authorities said. A7 NATIONAL A8-12 The Rapid Rise and Fall Of an Indian Drug Dealer Eugenia Phair, a Lummi Indian, is among the scores of drug traffickers who have flourished in an exploding drug trade on Indian lands. They are getting rich on their neighbors' addictions and capitalizing on gripping poverty or new-found casino wealth and on the weakness of law enforcement in Indian country, according to tribal and other officials and to Ms. Phair, who described her life as the leader of a drug trafficking ring in phone calls, letters and interviews over the last year. A1 Protected Wetlands in Court More than half of the nation's streams and wetlands could be removed from the protections of the federal Clean Water Act if legal challenges started more than a decade ago by two Michigan developers are supported by a majority of the newly remade Supreme Court. One case involves a developer who wanted to sell a wetland for a shopping center, and, in preparation, filled it with sand without applying for a permit. A8 Seeking Spy Program Approval After two months of insisting that President Bush did not need court approval to authorize wiretapping of calls between the United States and suspected terrorists abroad, the administration is now trying to channel the political pressure for more oversight into retroactive Congressional approval for the program. It is far from clear whether Mr. Bush can get the votes he will need. A9 Criticism of Ports Takeover Conditions set by the federal government for approving an Arab company's takeover of operations at six American ports are not enough to guard against terrorist infiltration, the chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee said. A9 Broader Deportation at Issue As the Bush administration rapidly expands its efforts to detain and deport illegal immigrants, human rights groups are warning that people fleeing persecution are becoming increasingly vulnerable to being deported to their home countries. In 2005, a bipartisan federal commission warned that some immigration officials were improperly processing asylum seekers for deportation. A9 Levee Upkeep Called Chaotic The Army Corps of Engineers is overlooking one of the most important causes of Hurricane Katrina's flooding of New Orleans: its own organizational failures, according to a new report from an outside engineering group working with the corps. The corps is spending about $20 million to understand the physical causes of the levee breaches that left more than 75 percent of New Orleans flooded. But the engineering group said the corps should also be looking into ''discontinuity and chaos'' in the creation and maintenance of the levees. A11 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Homeowners Turn Garages Into Status Symbols Homeowners in New York City's suburbs, and around the country, have latched onto garage organizing, spending $800 million on garage organizing products last year and making it one of the fastest-growing segments of the home improvement market. A1 Winter Runs Hot and Cold Eighteen times since Jan. 1, New York City's high temperature has fluctuated by 10 degrees or more from one day to the next. This past week, it felt as if a full year of weather was packed into several days. B3 SPORTSMONDAY D1-9 Continuing Fallout After Raid After their raid on Olympic athletes suspected of doping, the Italian police said they were testing items seized from the rooms of Austrian Nordic skiers, and Austrian Olympic officials said they had fired the coach at the center of the controversy. D1 OBITUARIES B7 ARTS E1-12 What the Met Knew, and When Documents show that the Metropolitan Museum of Art had concluded as early as 2003 that a set of Hellenistic silver it agreed to return to Italy last month might have been looted and should be returned. E1 The Politics of Superheroes America's current real-world political issues will wind themselves into the lives of the heroes of Marvel Comics in ''Civil War,'' a seven-issue limited monthly series set to begin in May. E3 BUSINESS DAY C1-8 Digital Moves to Top Tier As Sony, Panasonic and Samsung proceed with plans to move into photography's top tier with digital cameras, it may become a challenge for some of photography's most venerable brands simply to survive. C1 Slow Start for Cell Service Sprint, Verizon Wireless and other providers have spent billions of dollars upgrading their networks to lure customers to their new third-generation, or 3G, cellphones that play video and music, but it may be years before large numbers of consumers start signing up for the new services. C1 New Advance in Chips I.B.M. researchers plan to describe an advance in chip-making that could pave the way for new generations of superchips. The development will make it possible to create semiconductors with wires thinner than 30 nanometers, one-third the width in today's industry-standard chips. C4 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: Tollbooths on the Internet highway; the way to save; soaring eagles; William Blake and 'The Grave.' Columns: Bob Herbert and Paul Krugman. Autos D10 Bridge E10 Crossword E8 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E11 Weather B8

docs.lead_paragraph: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to expand the 311 information line to help pharmacists and older residents navigate the Medicare prescription drug benefit that took effect on Jan. 1. About 600,000 state residents have been enrolled in the program, and it is estimated that half live in New York City. Mr. Stringer said 311 should help older residents appeal denials of drug requests and inform them about subsidies to pay out-of-pocket costs. Several social service groups, including the Community Service Society of New York and the Medicare Rights Center, support the proposal. Stu Loeser, a spokesman for the mayor, said 311 callers are referred to a federal hot line, 1-800-MEDICARE (1-800-633-4227), and to 40 walk-in centers run by the city's Department for the Aging. Since November, those centers have counseled 16,500 residents on the new benefit and given presentations to 7,000 others. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Urged To Add Medicare Help To 311

docs.abstract: Manhattan Borough President Scott M Stringer urges Mayor Michael R Bloomberg to expand 311 telephone information line to help pharmacists and older residents with Medicare prescription drug benefit that took effect Jan 1 (S)
docs.snippet: The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to expand the 311 information line to help pharmacists and older residents navigate the Medicare prescription drug benefit that took effect on Jan. 1....

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: The cracks are still small in Canada's vaunted public health insurance system, but several of its largest provinces are beginning to open the way for private health care eventually to take root around the country. Last week Quebec proposed to lift a ban on private health insurance for several elective surgical procedures, and announced that it would pay for such surgeries at private clinics when waiting times at public facilities were unreasonable.

headline.main: Ruling Has Canada Planting Seeds of Private Health Care

docs.abstract: Several of Canada's largest provinces are beginning to open way for private health care; Quebec has proposed to lift ban on private health insurance for several elective procedures; proposal comes in response to Supreme Court decision that struck down law banning private medical insurance; decision applied directly to Quebec, but it has started movement for private clinics and private insurance in several provinces (M)
docs.snippet: The premier of British Columbia proposed a vision for a new health care system like those of Western Europe, which use both public and private facilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Working six-hour days at one of this city's busier intersections, where he cajoles pedestrians to respect the traffic signals, Li Debao has a hard-earned insight. ''Chinese people have some bad habits, and a lack of awareness of traffic rules is one of them,'' said the 36-year-old crossing guard. ''Two-thirds of the people ignore the rules, and simply can't be bothered.''

headline.main: A Pedestrian Drama That's Anything but Pedestrian

docs.abstract: Shanghai traffic guards have no powers of arrest or ability to issue tickets, allowing many pedestrians to ignore them or even physically assault them; 8,000 traffic guards use different tones of persuasion with flocks of pedestrians in city of 17 million; Shanghai's traffic is terrible at peak hours and steadily growing worse with city's runaway growth; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Shanghai's traffic would be frozen in perpetual gridlock without the work of traffic assistants.

docs.lead_paragraph: When New York State allowed Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to convert into a profit-making company in 2002, it set aside 5 percent of the proceeds for a foundation to continue the insurer's core mission -- providing health care to those who could not afford coverage. Now Gov. George E. Pataki is proposing that more than half of the foundation's $260 million endowment be redirected into biomedical research. And his plan to use that amount, $160 million, held by the fledgling New York Charitable Asset Foundation, has the support of the state's other top Republican, Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader in the State Senate.

headline.main: Pataki Plan to Use Insurer's Funds for Research Is Criticized

docs.abstract: Consumer groups and Assembly Democrats assail New York Gov George E Pataki's plan to direct $160 million of New York Charitable Asset Foundation's endowment to biomedical research; foundation, mandated to provide health care to poor, was created in 2002 as part of agreement when state allowed Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to become profit-making company; critics see Pataki approach, which has support of Senate majority leader Joseph L Bruno, as attempt to raid foundation; Pataki and Bruno say profits from conversion were higher than expected and foundation's 5 percent share exceeded what had been envisioned (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. George E. Pataki is proposing that more than half of the endowment of the New York Charitable Asset Foundation be redirected into biomedical research.

docs.lead_paragraph: Older voters, a critical component of Republican Congressional victories for more than a decade, could end up being a major vulnerability for the party in this year's midterm elections, according to strategists in both parties. Paradoxically, one reason is the new Medicare drug benefit, which was intended to cement their loyalty. During next week's Congressional recess, Democrats are set to begin a major new campaign to highlight what Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic leader, describes as ''this disastrous Republican Medicare prescription drug plan.''

headline.main: Drug Plan Tests Older Voters' Ties to G.O.P.

docs.abstract: Pollsters say Republicans' problems with over-60 vote go far beyond complicated drug benefit programs, which began Jan 1; Pres Bush's failed attempt to create private accounts in Social Security was also unpopular with older Americans; retirees loom large in midterm elections because they turn out in force and their numbers and influence are particularly strong in battleground states like Florida and Pennsylvania; Congressional Republicans increasingly say onus is on Pres Bush to make drug benefit program work; graphs; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Older voters could end up being a major vulnerability for the Republican Party in midterm elections, according to strategists.

docs.lead_paragraph: When carmakers recall a vehicle, they provide a replacement part and cover the cost of the labor to install it. But producers of expensive medical devices have found a better way -- they often have others, like taxpayers and insurers, pick up the labor cost. Last year, for example, when Medtronic and Guidant recalled certain heart defibrillators, both companies provided new devices free and agreed to reimburse patients up to $2,500 in out-of-pocket expenses for replacement operations. About 24,000 heart patients had such procedures; some 19,000 of them with Medtronic devices and an estimated 5,000 with Guidant units.
docs.abstract: Medical device makers usually have taxpayers and insurers cover labor costs of installing recall parts; publicly funded plans like Medicare and private insurers typically pay; in case of last year's recall of defibrillators from Medtronic and Guidant, costs of labor could reach tens, if not hundreds, of millions of dollars; health industry experts expect renewed debate due to latest round of recalls; Karen M Ignagni, president of trade group America's Health Insurance Plans, questions why insurers and customers should pay for manufacturer's mistakes; improvements must be made in tracking replacements and recouping costs (M)
docs.snippet: When producers of expensive medical devices recall their products, they make taxpayers or insurers pick up the hospital and doctor bills.
